Thank you, Principal of Hickory Career & Arts Magnet High (HCAM) Principal (and HPS Principal of the Year), Eric Puryear, for your encouraging words!

"Since March 16th, many students, teachers and administrators have been very anxious to know what school would look like Post-COVID. I am excited about the new direction that education is taking and I am excited to be able to interact and work with my students again this school year.

I am looking forward to seeing the hard work that HCAM and HPS have put into creating a robust remote learning plan come to fruition.

During the 2020 - 2021 school year there will be challenges, such as technology issues, COVID practices for safety measures, and the threat of COVID permeating the building. We hope to take the steps necessary to make sure that our school is clean and that we are following safety protocols for staying healthy. We hope with the abundance of resources provided that our teachers will be able to provide all students with the appropriate accommodations for their learning experience."

Thank you, Oakwood Principal, Terry Ashley, for your encouraging words!

"It's a whole lot different than our usual beginning of the school year, but at least we can 'see' our students online and interact with them. The development and nurturing of our relationships with students constantly reminds us of why we chose to become educators.

I'm looking forward to getting our students back in the building, but doing so safely. At the same time, I'm looking forward to watching our students and staff grow in their digital learning skills.

The challenge is making sure all of our students are able to connect with their teachers. We have addressed this issue by checking out devices for students to use, and providing them with assistance logging in and navigating through the digital learning environment. Our media coordinator, teachers, and assistants are doing a fabulous job providing continuous support and leading our students into a successful school year."

Thank you, Jeff Hodakowski, principal of Viewmont Elementary, for sharing your encouraging words!

‚ÄúIt is definitely a different type of year! I really enjoyed jumping into the Zoom meetings and 'seeing' our different students this morning! We are adapting the way instruction looks like to help meet the needs of all students. We have worked really hard to be ready for this day and will continue to work hard for our families!

I am looking forward to having students return when it is safe to do so. Until that time, I will focus on building connections with our families through other means. Communication is essential and I want families to know that I am here to help. Teachers are working extremely hard to make this a very successful year!

post_text:
Thank you, Hickory High History Teacher, Drew Daniels--for your honest and encouraging words!

"I'm excited to be back. Obviously I believe in the importance of education and I'm glad it's continuing in some form. And I think we all need to unpause our lives as much as health advisories allow.

The way to keep teaching fresh is to continually try new approaches. This year is going to provide ample opportunity! So I'm looking forward to the challenge of teaching the same content in an entirely different way and learning strategies for doing that. (Of course, I have some trepidation about that, too.)

Teaching is a people-oriented profession. I fear that distance learning is going to make getting to know my students far more difficult. I can't even see their expressions from the other side of a screen. I'll need to be intentional about allowing time in my lessons for human interaction and for creating a virtual classroom environment in which my students feel comfortable."

Thank you, Laura Beatty, music teacher at Longview Elementary, for your encouraging words!

"I'm so excited to be back in the classroom! But there is also that level of nerves and a little bit of feeling overwhelmed when I think about transitioning all of my lessons to completely online for these first few weeks.

I am most looking forward to seeing the students faces - even if it is through a screen! I am also looking forward to the new, innovative teaching methods I have learned to introduce and share material.

It is definitely a challenge figuring out how to teach music online when you can't all sing together because there is a delay or I don't have the opportunity to have them play the awesome instruments I have in my room. But we are making the best of it! We are singing all together but on mute. Pens and pencils have become drumsticks, it's actually pretty cool!"

"There has been a lot of anticipation regarding the beginning of this school year, and it is nice to be underway. Simply interacting with the students continues to be a highlight of my day.

I‚ÄôAsia Heard will attend Lenoir-Rhyne University.
